pullRequest.body:
Given a module over a topological ring, we define the module topology on this module to be the finest module making it into a topological module (i.e. the finest topology making addition and scalar multiplication continuous).

NB this PR gave rise to a discussion about whether `⨆ a ∈ s, f a` or `sSup (f '' s)` should be the simp normal form, which was discussed on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/normal.20form.20for.20pullback.20of.20Inf.20of.20topologies/near/472676441) without any clear conclusion.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

I wanted this because for a finite free module it can be checked to be the product topology, and for an algebra over a commutative topological ring which is finite as a module, multiplication in the algebra is automatically continuous with this topology. I have all of these results in the FLT repo [in this file](https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/FLT/blob/main/FLT/ForMathlib/ActionTopology.lean). What inspired me to PR it to mathlib was Yael's question [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Topology.20on.20a.20finite.20dimensional.20vector.20space/near/469687218) -- this topology gives a very nice answer to that question.

Thanks! I pushed two small golfs, feel free to merge before CI if they look fine to you. (I did test them)

bors d+

Thanks! I pushed two small golfs, feel free to merge before CI if they look fine to you. (I did test them)

```suggestion
* `ActionTopology.instSelf : IsActionTopology R R`. The action topology on `R` is `R`'s topology.
```

```suggestion
instance IsActionTopology.toContinuousSMul [TopologicalSpace A] [IsActionTopology R A] :
```
(and below for `ContinuousAdd`)

This is a proof type, so
```suggestion
  eq_actionTopology' : τA = actionTopology R A
```
Does this also work as `(gc_coinduced_induced f).l_sSup` or similar?

Annoyingly, no:
```
type mismatch
  GaloisConnection.l_sSup (gc_coinduced_induced g)
has type
  TopologicalSpace.coinduced g (sSup s) = ⨆ a ∈ s, TopologicalSpace.coinduced g a : Prop
but is expected to have type
  TopologicalSpace.coinduced g (sSup s) = sSup (TopologicalSpace.coinduced g '' s) : Prop
```
This works: `  rw [(gc_coinduced_induced f).l_sSup, sSup_image]`. Your comment made me realise I was using g instead of f though (i.e. I'd switched the roles of alpha and beta compared to the other lemmas), I've now fixed that. I don't even need this lemma, I only added it because I needed `induced_sInf` and I imagined that people would ask for the dual result in review.

I think the issue here is that we can't agree whether `⨆ a ∈ s, f a` or `sSup (f '' s)` is the preferred spelling, and so the library lemma uses the first and yours uses the second. I think @urkud prefers the former, but I'd argue that having `sSup` on both sides of the equality is more important, so I prefer the latter.

So are you arguing for `GaloisConnection.l_sSup'` with your preferred spelling? And should this be a separate PR? I am quite happy to dump this lemma completely in this PR, it's unused, it's only there for symmetry's sake.

The Zulip discussion [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/normal.20form.20for.20pullback.20of.20Inf.20of.20topologies/near/472676441) seems to indicate that what I'm doing here is fine.
I was just about to ask for these, but I guess I don't need to. Leaving them to a future PR is fine!
I figured 250 lines was plenty for the PR of the definition (about 50% of them are comments though!)

```suggestion
* The action topology is a functor from the category of `R`-modules
```
for markdown rendering

```suggestion
and `A` is an `R`-algebra of finite type as `R`-module, then `A` with its action
```

```suggestion
* The action topology is a functor from the category of `R`-modules
  to the category of topological `R`-modules, and it's an adjoint to the forgetful functor.
```

```suggestion
theorem eq_actionTopology [τA : TopologicalSpace A] [IsActionTopology R A] :
```
Oh yes -- thanks.
Should this be in the `Topology` or `TopologicalSpace` namespace? cc @urkud, @YaelDillies .
No strong opinion here

Yury said (via DM):

Namespace: Either root or TopologicalSpace is fine, because if it's in TopologicalSpace, then you can use letI : TopologicalSpace M := .actionTopology _

Naming: I would call it moduleTopology for the case if someone will separately define some topology associated with a MulAction.

```suggestion
  /-- Note that this should not be used directly, and `eq_actionTopology`, which takes `R` and `A` explicitly, should be used instead. -/
  eq_actionTopology' : τA = actionTopology R A
```

```suggestion
namespace IsActionTopology
```

```suggestion
instance _root_.TopologicalSemiring.toIsActionTopology (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [τR : TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R] :
```
can you add the `MulOpposite` action too?

Do you mean "prove `IsActionTopology R Rᵐᵒᵖ`? Or more generally "prove `IsActionTopology R M -> IsActionTopology R Mᵐᵒᵖ`? The simplest way to do this would be to deduce it from the fact that `M` and  `Mᵐᵒᵖ` are ContinuousLinearEquiv, and then it follows immediately from the results in this PR. However we don't seem to have this result; we have that they're isomorphic as R-modules and that they're homeomorphic, but we don't have the `ContinuousLinearEquiv`. Do you want me to make a new file adding only this result? In this PR? Or did I misunderstand?
I think you are misunderstanding. Eric is not talking about opposing the `M` but opposing the `R` instead

... and this really cannot be deduced from the `R R` version because the action is different (and incompatible with the identification of `R` with `R^mop`)

In general, if you can talk about `a * b`, then you can try talking about `a • b` or about `op b • a`. Currently, you have done the first but not the second.

If this is what Eric means then my comments above still apply, you just replace R with Rᵐᵒᵖ and Rᵐᵒᵖ with R (i.e. deduce it from the fact that Rᵐᵒᵖ has the action topology as a module over Rᵐᵒᵖ rather than the fact that R has the action topology as a module over R). So if my current understanding of what I'm being asked to do is correct, one solution would be to make a new file containing one result

```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites
import Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic

variable (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [τR : TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R]
  {M : Type*} [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] [TopologicalSpace M] [ContinuousSMul R M]

def MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv : M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ where
  __ := MulOpposite.opLinearEquiv R
```

(because that surely doesn't go in this file), and then in this file we add

```lean
instance mulOpposite (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R] :
    IsActionTopology Rᵐᵒᵖ R := .iso (MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv Rᵐᵒᵖ).symm
```

An alternative approach is to put `MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv` into `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic` and add `import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites` to that file (of length >= 2400 lines).

Thoughts?
But surely `R` isn't `R`-linearly isomorphic to `Rᵐᵒᵖ`?
Do we secretly have a diamond where `op a • op b` is both `op (b * a)` and `op (a * b)` depending on the instance you're inferring?

I slightly suspect [`MulOpposite.instMulAction`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Action/Opposite.html#MulOpposite.instMulAction) which defines `a • op b := op (a • b)` is the issue
I'm not really following this discussion, but I pushed a commit with the sorry filled.

> But surely `R` isn't `R`-linearly isomorphic to `Rᵐᵒᵖ`?

https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Opposites.html#MulOpposite.opLinearEquiv says `M ≃ₗ[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ`.

Can you clarify what you're worried about here?

Oh -- do you mean "But surely `R` isn't `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-linearly isomorphic to `Rᵐᵒᵖ`"?

I guess so yeah. I was working from the assumption that `R` would act on `Rᵐᵒᵖ` on the right, but that seems to be incorrect. All I'm saying is that `R` and `Rᵐᵒᵖ` are different as `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-modules (and should also be different as `R`-modules, but seem to be the same on current mathlib)

Just to be clear, in the context of "self-actions", the only two we care about are `Rᵐᵒᵖ` acting on `R`, and `R` acting on `R`. This was the only case I was talking about originally, and these should usually be on equal footing.

> All I'm saying is that R and Rᵐᵒᵖ are different as Rᵐᵒᵖ-modules 

This is false? Send `x` to `op x` and show `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-linearity by considering actions by `op r`: `op (op r • x) = op (x * r) = op r * op x = op r • op x`

> An alternative approach is to put `MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv` into `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic` and add `import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites` to that file (of length >= 2400 lines).

This sounds good to me.

Here is what we currently have:
```lean
import Mathlib

variable (R : Type*) [Semiring R]

open MulOpposite

example (a b : R) : a • b = a * b := rfl
example (a b : R) : (op a) • b = b * a := rfl
example (a b : R) : (op a) • (op b) = op (b * a) := rfl
example (a b : R) : a • (op b) = op (a * b) := rfl
```

I think I've got to the bottom of the confusion (Yael might have also done this). Yael is observing that in a parallel universe mathlib could have `a • (op b) = op (b * a)` because if someone asked for a natural left action of `R` on `Rᵐᵒᵖ` then one very reasonable response would be "well there's a natural right action of `R` on `R` so let's use that". This would break the symmetries in the above examples though. Indeed I would have *guessed* that `Rᵐᵒᵖ` and `R` would be different as `R`-modules (they're certainly not in general isomorphic as rings). However mathlib has made other decisions here.

> > An alternative approach is to put `MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv` into `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic` and add `import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites` to that file (of length >= 2400 lines).
> 
> This sounds good to me.

OK done. I've also (in another commit) changed the name to "module topology" following Yury's suggestion.

> > All I'm saying is that R and Rᵐᵒᵖ are different as Rᵐᵒᵖ-modules 
> 
> This is false? Send `x` to `op x` and show `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-linearity by considering actions by `op r`: `op (op r • x) = op (x * r) = op r * op x = op r • op x`
> 

I am now confused because I was dead certain one could not deduce the `R Rᵐᵒᵖ` result from the `R R` one

> > All I'm saying is that R and Rᵐᵒᵖ are different as Rᵐᵒᵖ-modules 
> 
> This is false? Send `x` to `op x` and show `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-linearity by considering actions by `op r`: `op (op r • x) = op (x * r) = op r * op x = op r • op x`
> 

I was confused because I was dead certain one could not deduce the `R Rᵐᵒᵖ` result from the `R R` one. I guess one actually can because the multiplication on `M` doesn't matter.

Yes that's the point: if R acts on M then the R-action on M^mop in mathlib is defined to be the R-action on M because in this generality there's no other choice. But when M=R there is a second choice because R acts naturally both on the left and right of M in this case.

Note that whilst this PR has exposed this issue, the PR has very little to do with it. We now have `IsModuleTopology Rᵐᵒᵖ R` with a one-line proof in this PR and I'm hoping that we can resolve this conversation.
Yes absolutely. I am happy to see it resolved.

nit:
```suggestion
    TopologicalSpace.induced g (sInf s) = sInf (TopologicalSpace.induced g '' s) := by
```
and below

I think this should be the definition; namely, `IsActionTopology` should mean "the canonical map from `WithActionTopology R` to `R` is continuous", where `WithActionTopology R` is a type synonym that puts the action topology on `R`.

This should eliminate all the `@`s below!
I tried this out in eric-wieser/withActionTopology, but there's a little more boilerplate needed than expected.
Are you suggesting I should refactor the definition in this PR?

After a private discussion with Eric he suggested that rather than the refactor I should add the lemma saying that if A is a topological module and the identity map from (A,standard) to (A,module topology) is continuous then A has the module topology. I've added this in `ad2d292`.

I think my one-line proof [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16895#discussion_r1796830218) (which uses the previous argument) is better than this (which redoes it). The problem with it is that it needs `M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ` and I don't know where to put this.

Oh nice, I missed that! Your proof confused me as much as it did @YaelDillies, but it does indeed seem to work and the types are all above-board! I think I'd argue tht you should hoist `.iso` toward the top of the file to keep the left and right versions toegther.
I've moved iso earlier, and I added `M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ` and the new import to the 2400-line file.

```suggestion
`R` as an `R`-module via `Semiring.toModule`. -/
```
and similarly for the instance below.
I think telling a mathematician "via `Semiring.toModule`" is much more confusing (to them) than telling them "...in the obvious way" so I've gone with both.
Perhaps it's worth a comment here or in the module docstring about how including `ContinuousNeg` is not necessary; maybe because in practice we derive this from `ContinuousSMul`.

I would imagine that in the situation where R did not have a neg but M did, there is a chance that neg on M is not continuous. I strongly believe that the mathematical definition of a [topological module](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_module) over a topological ring as being one where add and smul was continuous will have been made without any consideration whatsoever of the semiring case -- semirings are a mathlibism (nat is special-cased in mathematics and nnreal is just a subset of real without any attempt to build a theory on top of it; as far as I know all this semiring stuff is unique to mathlib).

Indeed how about R=nnreal, and M=real with the usual topology plus "every subset of (-infty,0] is open". Because the R-action can only push forward, I think M is a topological module in the sense of the natural generalisation of the Wikipedia definition, but neg is not continuous. Aah how about this: I say that *when R is a ring* ContinuousNeg is automatic.
OK I've rewritten a bunch of comments and in particular included the observation that neg is continuous in the ring case.

```suggestion
/-- `MulOpposite.op` as a continuous linear equivalence. -/
@[simps!]
def opContinuousLinearEquiv : M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ where
```

```suggestion
@[simps!]
def opContinuousLinearEquiv : M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ where
```
This is a long comment for a very small amount of proof!
Yes, and in my opinion more of mathlib should look like this! The proof of `continuousSMul_sInf` is slightly subtle I think. The comment explains the conceptual reason why it's true.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: topology on module over topological ring
